question_details.query: What actions can be taken to increase soil organic matter on agricultural land?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence from action documents indicates multiple practices associated with increases in soil organic matter or soil organic carbon on agricultural land: Including legumes or forage in crop rotations increased soil organic matter and soil organic carbon in several studies, though a few reported mixed or lower effects (857). Growing cover crops as living mulches or between rows increased soil organic matter in two controlled trials, with one trial finding no effect (897). Growing cover crops in fallow periods improved soil structure and nutrient retention, with studies reporting increased soil carbon and, in several trials, increased nitrogen and carbon under cover crops, although some European studies found no marked effect on soil organic matter (898). Applying manures and agricultural composts increased soil organic carbon in multiple studies and increased soil organic matter in one controlled, randomized, replicated study, while some studies found no effect on organic matter (911). Applying composts (not otherwise specified) at high rates increased soil organic matter and microbial biomass in a controlled, randomized, replicated trial (889). Incorporating fresh plant material or crop remains (e.g., straw) increased soil organic carbon across multiple studies and, in some cases, improved aggregation and reduced nitrate leaching (910). Retaining crop residues increased soil organic carbon and nitrogen in two randomized, replicated trials (907). Reduced tillage increased soil organic matter relative to conventional tillage in multiple replicated studies and a meta-analysis, though some studies found similar levels (1371). No-tillage increased soil organic matter relative to tilled soils in many replicated studies and a meta-analysis, with some studies finding mixed or similar results (1369). Changing tillage practices toward reduced or no-till increased soil organic carbon across numerous studies and often maintained or increased soil organic matter and improved soil structure, though results varied by context (906).

question_details.query: Which actions are most beneficial for increasing the diversity of soil organisms?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence linking actions to increased diversity or abundance of soil organisms includes: reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use, which was associated with higher diversity of soil invertebrates and microorganisms in low-input systems (904); growing cover crops when fields are empty, which resulted in more diverse nematode communities and, in one trial, greater microbial biomass under ryegrass than a ryegrass/vetch mix (898); using cover crops or ground cover in perennial crops, which increased microbial biomass in multiple studies, increased bacteria in one study, and increased nematode numbers in one comparison (2304); growing cover crops beneath the main crop or between rows (living mulches), which increased bacterial numbers and activity (897); no tillage as the main cultivation method, which often increased microbial biomass and increased earthworm numbers in two studies, with some studies reporting different nematode and mite communities (2306); reduced tillage, which frequently increased microbial biomass, increased denitrifying bacteria in one study, and increased earthworms in one of three comparisons (2307); establishing grass buffer strips, which increased microbial biomass in one study (2308); excluding grazers, which increased nematode numbers and nematode community diversity on a streambank (2309); amending soil with composts, which increased microbial biomass in one trial (889). Controlled traffic showed mixed results for microbial metrics: one study found higher numbers and bacterial activity under controlled traffic, while another found higher microbial biomass when traffic was not controlled (899). Adding sewage sludge did not change microbial biomass in two studies (2303).

question_details.query: What are the effects of amending soil with different types of organic materials?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across studies, adding organic materials to soil commonly increased microbial biomass and activity when manure was mixed with inorganic fertilizers, with manure alone also increasing microbial biomass; one trial found increased microbial diversity [902], and microbial biomass also rose when crop remains or straw were added [910] and when residues were retained [907]. Mixed organic–inorganic amendments raised soil organic carbon and nutrients in several trials, with manure alone also boosting carbon; one trial found inconsistent nutrient effects [902]; incorporating plant material increased soil carbon across multiple studies and sometimes increased aggregate size, and straw combined with NPK raised carbon [910]; retaining residues increased soil organic carbon and nitrogen, sometimes only when fertilizer was applied [907]. Straw addition reduced soil loss in one study, with mixed erosion effects depending on soil type [910]; residue retention reduced water runoff, increased water storage and reduced erosion, though some soil physical properties showed mixed responses and tillage influenced erosion when residues were removed [907]; mixed amendments reduced the size of cracks in dry soil compared to inorganic fertilizer alone or no fertilizer [902]. Nitrogen levels rose with compost or straw in several studies, and straw incorporation reduced nitrate leaching, although processed wastes showed mixed nutrient results and site effects were mixed in some comparisons [910]. Yields increased with mixed manure–inorganic amendments for maize [902]; barley yield rose with straw, and earlier incorporation of crop remains increased grain yields in one trial [910]; retaining residues increased yields, sometimes only with fertilizer and no-tillage [907]. Incorporating allelopathic plant remains sometimes reduced weeds relative to weeded or unweeded controls but effects varied by year, weed group or residue; suppression could be short-lived; crop growth was sometimes inhibited but could be mitigated by timing; yield effects were positive, negative or mixed, and profit exceeded unweeded but not weeded controls in one study [728]. In a salt marsh, adding organic alginate increased smooth cordgrass density and later plant height, while biomass after 52 weeks was similar to unamended plots [3244].

question_details.query: Besides retaining crop residues, what other actions can reduce soil erosion on agricultural land with clay soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Reduce grazing intensity: studies reported less sediment erosion when grazing time in forage crops was reduced, and increased soil carbon and nitrogen when grazing animals were excluded [901].
- Add mulch to crops: multiple trials found mulches increased soil stability and reduced soil erosion and runoff [887].
- Grow cover crops beneath the main crop or between rows (living mulches): studies from France and the USA showed reduced erosion and higher soil stability under cover crops [897].
- Plant or maintain ground cover in orchards/vineyards: six replicated, randomized, controlled studies found less soil erosion with ground cover compared to bare or tilled soils in some or all comparisons [1367].
- Amend soil with organic processing wastes or their composts: a controlled, replicated trial reported improved soil structure and reduced soil loss with high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure [891].
- Amend soil with non-chemical minerals and mineral wastes: replicated studies found reduced nutrient loss and, in one case, reduced erosion after mineral additions [892].
- Plant new hedges/hedgerows: replicated studies found hedgerows reduced soil erosion and increased soil organic matter [744].

question_details.query: What does the evidence say about the effectiveness of different soil amendments for improving crop yields on farms in Asia?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Green manures: Controlled, randomized, replicated studies from India and Pakistan found increased grain yields when green manures were grown [908].
- Retaining crop residues: Randomized, replicated trials reported higher yields in China when residues were retained, with one trial finding this only when residue retention was combined with fertilizer application and no-tillage [907].
- Incorporating fresh plant material/crop remains: A trial in the Philippines reported higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season [910].
- Soil microbial inoculants (bacteria or arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi): Randomized, replicated trials in India and Turkey found higher crop yields [888].
- Incorporating allelopathic plant remains: Across randomized, replicated, controlled studies that included Asia, yield effects were positive, negative, or mixed when compared with weeded controls; when compared with unweeded controls, two studies found positive effects and one found mixed effects [728].

question_details.query: What actions can be taken to reduce nutrient loss, specifically nitrates, from agricultural soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Applying nitrification inhibitors reduced nitrate losses in three of five trials, though one trial found no effect and application method influenced results [909]. Delaying ploughing until spring reduced nitrate leaching in replicated site comparisons [712]. Winter cover crops reduced nitrate leaching in four replicated, randomized, controlled studies, with one study finding similar leaching to fallow in some comparisons [1357]. Growing cover crops in empty fields reduced nitrate leaching in one study and improved nutrient retention and soil structure in others [898]. Reduced or no-tillage showed reduced soil loss and runoff in several trials, and one controlled, replicated trial found less nitrate in no-till compared to conventional tillage, while conventionally tilled soil lost more nitrate [906]. Adding slurry increased nitrate leaching in some replicated, randomized, controlled studies; less nitrate was leached with surface application compared to injection, and with lower slurry application rates [1380]. Applying farmyard or poultry manure reduced nutrient loss and increased nitrogen levels in some randomized, replicated studies, but one controlled, replicated study found higher nitrate leaching [911].

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence shows several organic soil management practices can increase crop yields: applying organic fertilizers sometimes produced higher yields than inorganic fertilizers in food and forage crops, though results were mixed across studies (1350). Applying composts (not otherwise specified) at high rates increased fruit yield in one controlled, randomized, replicated trial (889).

question_details.query: What are the wider soil health effects of amending soils with animal-derived products like manure or composts?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple controlled and replicated studies, applying manures or agricultural composts increased soil microbial biomass and activity, including higher microbial respiration with poultry manure [911, 902]. Manure applications reduced soil loss and water runoff in at least one trial when combined with other treatments [911], and high rates of cotton gin compost with poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss in another trial [891]. Nutrient outcomes were mixed: several trials reported higher soil nitrogen and reduced nutrient loss with farmyard or poultry manure, with timing (e.g., winter vs autumn) affecting losses [911], while other evidence showed increased nitrate leaching or increased nutrient loss at high compost/manure rates [911, 891]. Soil carbon generally rose with manure additions, with multiple trials and a review finding higher soil organic carbon under manure or mixed organic–inorganic regimes [911, 902], though effects on overall organic matter were inconsistent, with some studies showing increases in organic matter and aggregation under manure/compost and others showing no change [911]. Mixed organic–inorganic amendments frequently increased microbial diversity/activity, nutrients, and organic carbon, and improved dry-soil physical condition compared with inorganic-only inputs [902]. Crop yields often improved with manure or compost, including gains when combined with cover crops or in mixed amendment systems [911, 902], and barley yield increased with added molasses in one trial [891].

question_details.query: What are the documented benefits and drawbacks of converting to low-input or organic farming systems?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Evidence on low‑input/organic systems reports mixed outcomes across taxa: For bats, farms or grasslands with few or no chemical inputs had higher overall bat activity than high‑input sites in Portugal and Germany, coffee agroforestry with few/no chemicals had higher diversity of insect‑eating bats (but not fruit/nectar‑eating bats) in Mexico, and bats in Colombian silvopastoral areas without chemicals had higher body weight and condition; farms using fewer/no chemicals also showed different bat community composition compared to high‑input farms [2013]. Comparing organic vs conventional farms, multiple studies found either no difference in bat species richness or higher richness on organic farms in some cases; bat activity was sometimes higher on organic farms (overall activity, feeding activity, Brazilian free‑tailed bat activity, and activity of some species), with other studies finding no difference; higher activity of Myotis spp. over water/rivers and for some species over organic fields was also reported [961]. For butterflies and moths, several studies found greater species richness and abundance on organic arable farms than conventional, sometimes increasing with time since conversion, while other studies found similar richness/abundance; in one before‑and‑after study, two butterfly species decreased after conversion alongside other management changes; effects varied with landscape context and farm age in multiple studies [3907]. For mammals, reducing pesticide/fertilizer use did not increase small mammal species richness or use of field margins in Argentina; one UK/Italy study found increased wood mouse abundance with organic farming, while another found no increase for European hare [2539]. For conversion to organic agriculture/aquaculture near peatlands, no studies were found assessing effects on peatland vegetation [1785].

Which actions are most effective for increasing soil microbial biomass?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Amending soil with mixed organic and inorganic amendments increased microbial biomass and activity in multiple controlled trials; manure alone also increased microbial biomass [902]. Applying a high rate of compost increased microbial biomass in one controlled, randomized, replicated trial [889]. Growing cover crops increased microbial biomass in several studies, with five replicated, randomized, controlled studies finding more microbial biomass and one study reporting inconsistent differences; one trial found greater microbial biomass under ryegrass than a ryegrass/vetch mix [1345, 898]. In perennial systems, cover or ground covers increased microbial biomass in some or all comparisons across four replicated studies [2304]. Reduced tillage increased microbial biomass in many comparisons (11 of 15 studies), though some studies found less or no difference compared to conventional tillage [1371, 2307]. No-tillage sometimes increased, sometimes decreased, and sometimes did not change microbial biomass, though several studies reported higher microbial biomass without tillage [2306]. Grass buffer strips increased microbial biomass in one replicated, randomized, controlled study [2308]. Adding sewage sludge produced similar microbial biomass to controls in two studies [2303]. Including legumes in rotations showed mixed effects on microbial biomass (more in some comparisons, less in others) [2305, 1368].

question_details.query: What are some of the most effective actions for reducing soil erosion on agricultural land?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Across multiple studies, growing cover crops or living mulches beneath or between crop rows reduced soil erosion: a controlled study reported highest soil stability under a grass cover, and a randomized, replicated study found reduced soil loss under cover crops, with additional studies from France and the USA showing reduced erosion (897). Adding mulch to crops increased soil stability and reduced soil erosion and runoff in five studies from India, France, Nigeria and the UK, with one trial noting that some mulch types were more effective than others (887). Adding sewage sludge to soil produced mixed results for erosion-related metrics: one replicated, controlled study in Spain found less erosion with added sewage sludge, while a replicated, controlled study in the USA found no difference in soil stability (1364).

question_details.query: On agricultural land, what are the documented benefits and drawbacks of amending soil with manures or municipal wastes?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Documented benefits include higher microbial biomass with manure or compost applications and higher microbial respiration with poultry manure [911]; reduced soil loss and water runoff when municipal compost was added to semi-arid soils [890]; reduced soil loss and water runoff when manure was applied in combination with other treatments [911]; reduced nutrient loss and higher nitrogen levels with farmyard or poultry manure, with lower nutrient loss when farmyard manure was applied in winter rather than autumn [911]; higher soil carbon with manure applications [911]; improved soil physical properties, including larger soil aggregates and higher organic matter, when manure and compost were applied [911]; increased crop yields with manure or compost, including when combined with cover crops [911]; increased grain yields or higher soil organic carbon when green manures were grown [908]. Documented drawbacks include higher nitrate leaching in one study after manure application [911]; increased nutrient loss when high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure were applied [891]; and mixed results for municipal composts and wastes in one trial [890].

question_details.query: What actions are available to improve the physical structure of clay and clay-loam soils?

summary_details.relevant_summary:
- Amend with fresh plant material or crop remains: studies found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated and larger soil aggregates; soils covered include clay and clay-loam [910].
- Add mulch to crops: one trial showed mulch improved soil structure; multiple studies reported increased soil stability and reduced erosion and runoff; soils covered include clay [887].
- Control traffic and traffic timing: trials reported a higher number of soil pores, less compaction, reduced runoff, and increased water infiltration; soils covered include clay [899].
- Reduce grazing intensity/exclude grazing: a replicated study found compacted soils recovered when sheep were excluded for 2.5 years; soils covered include clay and clay-loamy [901].
- Use crop rotation (including legumes/forage): studies found increased water infiltration, reduced runoff and soil loss, and increased soil organic carbon; soils covered include clay and clay-loam [857].
